answer: ['During WW2 in Germany and I believe Austria, many kids and babies who were institutionalized for disabilities were killed by being out outside without sufficient clothes so they would get pneumonia and die.   Institutions tend to be mental hospitals or called insane asylums. People there get maintenance care at best.', 'During WW2 in Germany and I believe Austria, many kids and babies who were institutionalized for disabilities were killed by being out outside without sufficient clothes so they would get pneumonia and die.   Institutions tend to be mental hospitals or called insane asylums. People there get maintenance care at best.', 'Each time you fold a sheet of paper it doubles in size. Obviously you can\'t ACTUALLY fold a sheet of paper 42 times, but if you could, here\'s how it would work:  if 500 sheets of paper are about 2" as you say, 1 sheet would be 0.004 inches.  1 fold would make 0.008 inches (0.004 * 2^1)  2 folds would make 0.016 inches (0.004 * 2^2)  so 42 folds is 0.004 * 2^42 = 17592186044.4 inches = 277,654.45 miles.  The distance to the moon is 238,855 miles (give or take, depending on orbit)', 'Each time you fold a sheet of paper it doubles in size. The distance to the moon is 238,855 miles (give or take, depending on orbit)', "In engineering risk assessment there is a theory called the cheese model. Imagine many slices of cheese, each with some holes in random positions. Each slice of cheese represents one entity in the engineering project, and holes represent safety holes in that one entity. A risk factor (hole) in one entity can be blocked by another entity. However, sometimes you're unlucky and all the holes align. Everything is at the wrong place at the same time, and disaster happens.   Truth is, humans *will* make mistakes. It is unavoidable. Any attempts to reduce risk *will* cause risks of its own. The best we can do is to have many layers of cheese (safety mechanism) so that the chance of holes aligning (all safety mechanisms failing) is as small as possible. The desire to blame a single entity for disasters is not only wrong, but also makes the entire system prone to future disasters. If we only blame one slice of cheese for the entire disaster, problems in every other slice of cheese is not fixed, or even worse, those holes get larger due to complacency.", "In engineering risk assessment there is a theory called the cheese model. Imagine many slices of cheese, each with some holes in random positions. Each slice of cheese represents one entity in the engineering project, and holes represent safety holes in that one entity. A risk factor (hole) in one entity can be blocked by another entity. However, sometimes you're unlucky and all the holes align. Everything is at the wrong place at the same time, and disaster happens.   Truth is, humans *will* make mistakes. It is unavoidable. Any attempts to reduce risk *will* cause risks of its own. The best we can do is to have many layers of cheese (safety mechanism) so that the chance of holes aligning (all safety mechanisms failing) is as small as possible. You probably heard that files are stored as "a bunch of 0s and 1s". Well those 0s and 1s are basically stored is super-tiny switches that can be set in 2 different positions (called 0 and 1). One Byte is 8 such switches, so 1 TB is 8 *trillions* of such very tiny switches. warp"', 'What are some examples of energy transformations necessary to maintain the fabric of spacetime?', "Why would it require some continuous transfer of energy?  The object simply exists and has this effect.  Transfer of energy would mean that the energy is being transferred from the object to the observer.  The observer is just a thing that exists, just like the air is just air. Transfer of a significant amount of energy requires a process called energy transfer.   If the object is just an object that exists and moves in space, then transfer of the energy would be no problem.  If it were a moving object that moved in a direction that required energy, then the transfer would be from the observer to the moving object.  But since it's just a small object that moves in a certain direction, there's no reason it should require energy.  In fact, it's the opposite: the movement of the object towards the observer causes the energy to be transferred from that point to the object.", 'Can you explain the concept of a gravitational field and its role in the conservation of mass?', 'What is the role of the brainstem in initiating the transition from wakefulness to sleep?', 'Can you explain what is meant by "rapid brain activity" during sleep transition?', 'How does the brain normally regulate internal body temperature during sleep?', 'Why might a sudden awakening occur during a hypnic jerk?']
